content.text: Pour approximately \(3 \mathrm{cm}^3\) of water into the boiling tube
Measure the height \(h_0\) of the water level from the bench, as shown in Fig. 1.1
Suggest **one** precaution that is taken when measuring the height of the water level to ensure the reading is accurate
You may draw a diagram if it helps your explanation
Using the dropping pipette, and measuring cylinder if necessary, add a further volume of water \(V = 5.0 \text{cm}^3\) to the water already in the boiling tube
Measure, and record in Table 1.1, the new height \(h\) of the water level from the bench

Repeat this procedure, adding \(5.0 \text{cm}^3\) of water each time so that the total volume of water added \(V = 10.0 \text{cm}^3\), \(15.0 \text{cm}^3\), \(20.0 \text{cm}^3\) and \(25.0 \text{cm}^3\)

For each value of \(V,\) calculate, and record in Table 1.1, the increase in height \(H\) of the water in the boiling tube. Use your value of \(h_0\) from (a), the values of \(h\) in Table 1.1 and the equation \(H = (h - h_0)\)
Plot a graph of \(V / \text{cm}^3\) (\(y\)-axis) against \(H / \text{cm}\) (\(x\)-axis)
Determine the gradient of the graph. Show clearly on the graph how you obtained the necessary information
gradient =   .........
Calculate \(D\), the inside diameter of the boiling tube
Use the equation \(D = \sqrt{\frac{4G}{\pi}}\), where \(G\) is numerically equivalent to the gradient in (e)(i)
Suggest why it is important to add a small amount of water at the start of the experiment

A student uses this experiment to measure \(D\) for a small test-tube of diameter approximately \(1.2 \text{cm}\) and length \(7.5 \text{cm}\). He adds water in volumes of \(1.0 \text{cm}^3\) at a time
State and explain **one** reason why this is **not** an accurate method to use for this test-tube
In this experiment, you will investigate the dimensions of a boiling tube
The apparatus has been set up for you
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 1.1
Remove the lid from beaker A
Pour \(150 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into beaker A and replace the lid
Place the thermometer in the water
In the first row of Table 2.1, record the temperature \(\theta\) of the water at time \(t = 0\) and immediately start the stop-clock
Record the temperature \(\theta\) of the water at \(t = 30 \text{s}\), \(t = 60 \text{s}\), \(t = 90 \text{s}\), \(t = 120 \text{s}\), \(t = 150 \text{s}\) and \(t = 180 \text{s}\)
Remove the thermometer from the beaker
Repeat (a) for beaker B
Add units to the column headings in Table 2.1
Write a conclusion stating if the colour of the outside surface of the beaker affects the rate of cooling of the water in the beaker
Justify your answer by reference to values from your results
Calculate the average cooling rate \(x_{\mathrm{A}}\) for the water in beaker A during the experiment
Use your readings for beaker A from Table 2.1 and the equation
where \(T = 180 \text{s}\) and \(\theta_0\) and \(\theta_{180}\) are the temperatures of the water in beaker A at times \(t = 0\) and \(t = 180 \text{s}\)
Include the unit for the cooling rate
Calculate the average cooling rate \(x_{\mathrm{B}}\) for the water in beaker B during the experiment. Use your readings for beaker B from Table 2.1 and the equation
where \(T = 180 \text{s}\) and \(\theta_0\) and \(\theta_{180}\) are the temperatures of the water in beaker B at times \(t = 0\) and \(t = 180 \text{s}\)
Include the unit
A student states that the black card is a thermal insulator. He thinks this will affect the result
Suggest an additional experiment to test this theory
You are **not** required to carry out this additional experiment
Suggest one variable which should be kept the same for this additional experiment so that the comparison with your experiment is fair. Assume that the same type of beaker is used
State how the cooling rate of beaker A from the additional experiment is likely to compare with \(x_{\mathrm{A}}\) from (d)(i) if the student's theory is correct. Explain your answer
statement
explanation
In this experiment, you will investigate the effect of the colour of the outside surface of a beaker on the rate of cooling of water in the beaker
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 2.1
Beaker A is covered with thin black card
Beaker B is covered with shiny metal foil
Close the switch
Measure the potential difference (p.d.) \(V\) across the parallel combination of resistors P and Q
Measure the current \(I_{\mathrm{T}}\) in the circuit
Open the switch
Calculate the resistance \(R_{\mathrm{PQ}}\) of the parallel combination of resistors P and Q
Use your readings from (a)(i) and the equation \(R_{\mathrm{PQ}} = \frac{V}{I_{\mathrm{T}}}\)
Disconnect the voltmeter and reconnect it to measure the potential difference across resistor S
Close the switch
Measure the potential difference \(V_{\mathrm{S}}\) across resistor S
Open the switch
Disconnect the voltmeter from the circuit
Calculate the resistance \(R_{\mathrm{S}}\) of resistor S
Use your readings from (a)(i), (a)(iii) and the equation \(R_{\mathrm{S}} = \frac{V_{\mathrm{S}}}{I_{\mathrm{T}}}\)
Disconnect the ammeter and reconnect it as shown in Fig. 3.2
Close the switch
Measure the current \(I_{\mathrm{p}}\) in resistor P
Open the switch
Disconnect the ammeter and reconnect it as shown in Fig. 3.3
Close the switch
Measure the current \(I_{\mathrm{Q}}\) in resistor Q
Open the switch
A student suggests that \(I_{\mathrm{T}}\) should be equal to \(I_{\mathrm{P}} + I_{\mathrm{Q}}\)
State whether your results support this suggestion. Justify your statement by reference to values from your results
statement
justification
A student changes the circuit and uses a variable resistor to control the current in the circuit
In the space provided, draw the circuit symbol for a variable resistor
Mark with an X on Fig. 3.3 where a variable resistor is connected to control the current in resistor S without affecting the resistance of either of the parallel branches.
The current in the circuit can be controlled by connecting a range of different resistors in place of resistors P and Q
State one disadvantage of this method instead of using a variable resistor to control the current
In this experiment, you will investigate circuits containing resistors in parallel
The first circuit has been set up for you
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 3.1
All numeric answers must have appropriate units
A student investigates the effect of temperature on the bounce height of a squash ball. A squash ball is a hollow rubber ball approximately 4 cm in diameter
Plan an experiment to investigate how the bounce height of the ball changes as the temperature of the ball rises
You are **not** required to carry out the experiment
The apparatus available includes:
a selection of squash balls
standard laboratory heating equipment
a beaker large enough for the squash ball to fit inside
a supply of cold water
In your plan, you should:
list any additional apparatus needed
explain briefly how to do the experiment, including any precautions to ensure reliable results (you may draw a diagram below if it helps to explain your plan)
state the key variables to be kept constant
draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how to display the readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)
explain how to use the readings to reach a conclusion
